Introduction

Show Chapter Summary
Following a lengthy court case, an appeals court confirms a ruling that assigns custody of a child to her father, Beale Farange. The court also orders the father to refund £2,600 to his ex-wife, Ida. The father is unable to produce the money. After another dispute, their lawyers propose a compromise that both sides accept. The father's debt is forgiven, and the parents agree to a new custody arrangement. The child will live with each parent for six months at a time, in rotation. A female relative of the mother then offers to take the child herself, but the mother rejects the offer. It is noted that the child has her own income from a trust fund left by the father's deceased aunt. The Faranges' friends gather and argue about the couple and their situation.

[Original]

The litigation seemed interminable and had in fact been complicated; but by the decision on the appeal the judgement of the divorce-court was confirmed as to the assignment of the child. The father, who, though bespattered from head to foot, had made good his case, was, in pursuance of this triumph, appointed to keep her: it was not so much that the mother's character had been more absolutely damaged as that the brilliancy of a lady's complexion (and this lady's, in court, was immensely remarked) might be more regarded as showing the spots. Attached, however, to the second pronouncement was a condition that detracted, for Beale Farange, from its sweetness—an order that he should refund to his late wife the twenty-six hundred pounds put down by her, as it was called, some three years before, in the interest of the child's maintenance and precisely on a proved understanding that he would take no proceedings: a sum of which he had had the administration and of which he could render not the least account. The obligation thus attributed to her adversary was no small balm to Ida's resentment; it drew a part of the sting from her defeat and compelled Mr.

Translation

The legal proceedings dragged on endlessly and had, in reality, been quite complex. However, the appellate court's decision upheld the divorce court's ruling regarding custody of the child. The father, though thoroughly smeared, had ultimately prevailed and, as a consequence of his victory, was granted custody. It wasn't that the mother's reputation was more severely tarnished, but rather that a woman's attractiveness—and this particular woman's appearance in court was widely discussed—could be seen as revealing her flaws. Nevertheless, this second ruling included a condition that lessened the victory's impact for Beale Farange: an order to reimburse his ex-wife the twenty-six hundred pounds she had provided, approximately three years earlier, for the child's care, with the explicit understanding that he wouldn't pursue legal action. He had managed the money but couldn't provide any accounting for it. This obligation placed on her opponent somewhat eased Ida's bitterness; it softened the blow of her loss and forced Mr.

[Original]

Farange perceptibly to lower his crest. He was unable to produce the money or to raise it in any way; so that after a squabble scarcely less public and scarcely more decent than the original shock of battle his only issue from his predicament was a compromise proposed by his legal advisers and finally accepted by hers. His debt was by this arrangement remitted to him and the little girl disposed of in a manner worthy of the judgement-seat of Solomon. She was divided in two and the portions tossed impartially to the disputants.

Translation

Farange visibly deflated. He couldn't produce the money, nor could he find a way to get it. So, after a dispute that was almost as public and just as unsavory as the original battle, his only escape from the situation was a compromise suggested by his own lawyers and eventually agreed to by hers. Through this arrangement, his debt was forgiven, and the little girl was dealt with in a way that would have done justice to the judgment of Solomon. She was divided in two, and the portions were handed out impartially to the litigants.

[Original]

They would take her, in rotation, for six months at a time; she would spend half the year with each. This was odd justice in the eyes of those who still blinked in the fierce light projected from the tribunal—a light in which neither parent figured in the least as a happy example to youth and innocence. What was to have been expected on the evidence was the nomination, in loco parentis, of some proper third person, some respectable or at least some presentable friend. Apparently, however, the circle of the Faranges had been scanned in vain for any such ornament; so that the only solution finally meeting all the difficulties was, save that of sending Maisie to a Home, the partition of the tutelary office in the manner I have mentioned.

Translation

They would have her in rotation, spending six months with each parent. Half the year with one, half with the other. Those still struggling to adjust to the intense scrutiny of the court found this a strange form of justice. Neither parent was a good role model for a child. Based on the evidence, the expectation was that the court would appoint a suitable third party, a respectable friend, to act in place of the parents. However, the Farange family's social circle contained no such person. Barring the option of placing Maisie in an institution, the only way to resolve the situation was to divide parental responsibility, as I have described.

[Original]

There were more reasons for her parents to agree to it than there had ever been for them to agree to anything; and they now prepared with her help to enjoy the distinction that waits upon vulgarity sufficiently attested. Their rupture had resounded, and after being perfectly insignificant together they would be decidedly striking apart. Had they not produced an impression that warranted people in looking for appeals in the newspapers for the rescue of the little one—reverberation, amid a vociferous public, of the idea that some movement should be started or some benevolent person should come forward? A good lady came indeed a step or two: she was distantly related to Mrs.

Translation

There were more reasons for her parents to agree to this than they had ever had for agreeing to anything; and with her help, they now prepared to savor the acclaim that awaited proven vulgarity. Their split had been dramatic, and after being utterly unremarkable together, they would be undeniably noticeable apart. Hadn't they made such an impression that people expected to see pleas in the newspapers for the little one's rescue—the echo, among a clamoring public, of an idea that some initiative should be launched or some charitable soul should step forward? A good woman did, in fact, make an effort: she was distantly related to Mrs. Farange.

[Original]

Farange, to whom she proposed that, having children and nurseries wound up and going, she should be allowed to take home the bone of contention and, by working it into her system, relieve at least one of the parents. This would make every time, for Maisie, after her inevitable six months with Beale, much more of a change. "More of a change?" Ida cried. "Won't it be enough of a change for her to come from that low brute to the person in the world who detests him most?"

Translation

Farange, to whom she suggested that, since children and their nurseries were established and functioning, she ought to be permitted to take the core issue and, by integrating it into her own life, alleviate at least one parent's burden. This would make each period, for Maisie, after her unavoidable six months with Beale, a significantly bigger transition. "Bigger transition?" Ida exclaimed. "Isn't it change enough for her to go from that vile man to the individual on Earth who despises him most?"

[Original]

"No, because you detest him so much that you'll always talk to her about him. You'll keep him before her by perpetually abusing him." Mrs. Farange stared.

Translation

"No, because you hate him so much you'll always talk about him with her. You'll keep him present in her mind by constantly speaking ill of him." Mrs. Farange stared.

[Original]

"Pray, then, am I to do nothing to counteract his villainous abuse of me?" The good lady, for a moment, made no reply: her silence was a grim judgement of the whole point of view. "Poor little monkey!" she at last exclaimed; and the words were an epitaph for the tomb of Maisie's childhood. She was abandoned to her fate.

Translation

"So, am I just supposed to do nothing to counter

his vile attacks on me?" The woman didn't respond for a moment; her silence was a harsh critique of the entire perspective. "Poor little thing!" she finally exclaimed; and the words were an epitaph for the grave of Maisie's childhood. She was left to her own devices.

[Original]

What was clear to any spectator was that the only link binding her to either parent was this lamentable fact of her being a ready vessel for bitterness, a deep little porcelain cup in which biting acids could be mixed. They had wanted her not for any good they could do her, but for the harm they could, with her unconscious aid, do each other. She should serve their anger and seal their revenge, for husband and wife had been alike crippled by the heavy hand of justice, which in the last resort met on neither side their indignant claim to get, as they called it, everything. If each was only to get half this seemed to concede that neither was so base as the other pretended, or, to put it differently, offered them both as bad indeed, since they were only as good as each other.

Translation

It was obvious to anyone watching that the only connection she had to either parent was this: she was a convenient receptacle for their bitterness. She was a tiny, delicate porcelain cup in which they could mix their poisonous hatred. They didn't want her for any benefit they could give her, but for the damage they could inflict on each other, with her unwitting help. She was meant to channel their anger and be the instrument of their revenge. Both husband and wife were equally wounded by the harsh verdict of the law, which ultimately didn't side with either of their outraged demands to, as they put it, get everything. If each was only to get half, it was as if they both admitted that neither was as terrible as the other claimed. Or, to put it another way, it made them both appear equally bad, since they were only as good as one another.

[Original]

The mother had wished to prevent the father from, as she said, "so much as looking" at the child; the father's plea was that the mother's lightest touch was "simply contamination." These were the opposed principles in which Maisie was to be educated—she was to fit them together as she might. Nothing could have been more touching at first than her failure to suspect the ordeal that awaited her little unspotted soul. There were persons horrified to think what those in charge of it would combine to try to make of it: no one could conceive in advance that they would be able to make nothing ill. This was a society in which for the most part people were occupied only with chatter, but the disunited couple had at last grounds for expecting a time of high activity.

Translation

The mother wanted to keep the father from even “looking” at the child, while the father argued that the mother’s mere touch was “simply contamination.” These were the conflicting ideas that Maisie was to learn—she was supposed to reconcile them as best she could. At first, nothing could have been more poignant than her complete unawareness of the suffering that awaited her innocent soul. Some people were horrified by what her guardians would conspire to do to her; no one could have predicted they would end up accomplishing nothing truly harmful. This was a world largely consumed by meaningless conversation, but this fractured couple finally had reason to expect a period of intense action.

[Original]

They girded their loins, they felt as if the quarrel had only begun. They felt indeed more married than ever, inasmuch as what marriage had mainly suggested to them was the unbroken opportunity to quarrel. There had been "sides" before, and there were sides as much as ever; for the sider too the prospect opened out, taking the pleasant form of a superabundance of matter for desultory conversation. The many friends of the Faranges drew together to differ about them; contradiction grew young again over teacups and cigars.

Translation

They steeled themselves, feeling as though the conflict had just begun. In fact, they felt more married than ever, since what marriage mainly offered them was the endless chance to argue. There had been “sides” before, and there were sides still; for each faction, the prospect blossomed, taking the pleasing form of a surplus of material for casual conversation. The numerous friends of the Faranges gathered, disagreeing among themselves; contradiction was reborn over tea and cigars.

[Original]

Everybody was always assuring everybody of something very shocking, and nobody would have been jolly if nobody had been outrageous. The pair appeared to have a social attraction which failed merely as regards each other: it was indeed a great deal to be able to say for Ida that no one but Beale desired her blood, and for Beale that if he should ever have his eyes scratched out it would be only by his wife. It was generally felt, to begin with, that they were awfully good-looking—they had really not been analysed to a deeper residuum. They made up together for instance some twelve feet three of stature, and nothing was more discussed than the apportionment of this quantity.

Translation

Everyone was constantly making some shocking claim to someone else, and no one could have been happy unless someone was being outrageous. The couple seemed to possess a social magnetism that didn't work for each other. It was, in fact, a great accomplishment for Ida that no one other than Beale wanted to harm her, and for Beale that only his wife would ever be the cause of him losing his sight. Initially, they were generally considered to be incredibly attractive—they hadn't really been examined for any deeper qualities. For instance, together they totaled about twelve feet three inches in height, and the distribution of that height was the topic of endless conversation.

[Original]

The sole flaw in Ida's beauty was a length and reach of arm conducive perhaps to her having so often beaten her ex-husband at billiards, a game in which she showed a superiority largely accountable, as she maintained, for the resentment finding expression in his physical violence. Billiards was her great accomplishment and the distinction her name always first produced the mention of. Notwithstanding some very long lines everything about her that might have been large and that in many women profited by the licence was, with a single exception, admired and cited for its smallness. The exception was her eyes, which might have been of mere regulation size, but which overstepped the modesty of nature; her mouth, on the other hand, was barely perceptible, and odds were freely taken as to the measurement of her waist.

Translation

The only fault in Ida's beauty was the length and reach of her arms, which probably helped her beat her ex-husband at billiards so often. She was superior at the game, a fact that she claimed explained the resentment that led to his physical violence. Billiards was her greatest achievement, the thing her name was always mentioned with. Despite her very long limbs, everything about her that could have been large and that in many women was considered an asset, was, with one exception, admired and celebrated for its smallness. The exception was her eyes, which could have been normal-sized, but which exceeded the limits of modesty. Her mouth, on the other hand, was barely visible, and people freely bet on the measurement of her waist.

[Original]

She was a person who, when she was out—and she was always out—produced everywhere a sense of having been seen often, the sense indeed of a kind of abuse of visibility, so that it would have been, in the usual places rather vulgar to wonder at her. Strangers only did that; but they, to the amusement of the familiar, did it very much: it was an inevitable way of betraying an alien habit. Like her husband she carried clothes, carried them as a train carries passengers: people had been known to compare their taste and dispute about the accommodation they gave these articles, though inclining on the whole to the commendation of Ida as less overcrowded, especially with jewellery and flowers. Beale Farange had natural decorations, a kind of costume in his vast fair beard, burnished like a gold breastplate, and in the eternal glitter of the teeth that his long moustache had been trained not to hide and that gave him, in every possible situation, the look of the joy of life.

Translation

She was a person who, whenever she was out—and she was always out—gave off the impression of being frequently observed, an effect bordering on an overuse of visibility. Consequently, it would have seemed rather crude in the usual settings to express amazement at her. Only strangers did that, though they did so quite emphatically, much to the amusement of those who knew her. It was an inevitable way of revealing unfamiliarity. Like her husband, she bore her clothes, carried them as a train carries its passengers. People were known to compare their fashion sense and debate the way they accommodated their attire, generally favoring Ida, considering her style less cluttered, particularly when it came to jewelry and flowers. Beale Farange had natural embellishments, a sort of inherent costume in his expansive, fair beard, gleaming like a golden breastplate, and in the constant sparkle of his teeth, which his long mustache was trained not to conceal. These features gave him, in every possible situation, the appearance of someone overflowing with the joy of living.

[Original]

He had been destined in his youth for diplomacy and momentarily attached, without a salary, to a legation which enabled him often to say "In my time in the East": but contemporary history had somehow had no use for him, had hurried past him and left him in perpetual Piccadilly. Every one knew what he had—only twenty-five hundred. Poor Ida, who had run through everything, had now nothing but her carriage and her paralysed uncle. This old brute, as he was called, was supposed to have a lot put away.

Translation

In his youth, he'd been slated for a career in diplomacy. He'd even briefly worked, without pay, at a legation, which allowed him to frequently declare, "In my time in the East." But contemporary history had somehow disregarded him, moving on without him and leaving him stranded in perpetual Piccadilly. Everyone knew his financial situation—a mere twenty-five hundred. Poor Ida, having squandered everything, now possessed only her carriage and her paralyzed uncle. This old curmudgeon, as he was known, was believed to have a considerable fortune stashed away.

[Original]

The child was provided for, thanks to a crafty godmother, a defunct aunt of Beale's, who had left her something in such a manner that the parents could appropriate only the income.

Translation

The child was provided for, thanks to a shrewd godmother, a deceased aunt of Beale's, who had bequeathed the child something in a way that only the income could be accessed by the parents.

Chapter I

Show Chapter Summary
A young girl, Maisie, lives with her father under a new arrangement. Her father shows her letters from her mother, shakes them at her, and then throws them into the fire. Men who visit the father pinch Maisie’s features and the calves of her legs until she shrieks, and they have her light their cigarettes. Her nurse, Moddle, tells Maisie that her father has been greatly inconvenienced on her account. Maisie is told her mother will soon come to take her away. To prepare her, Moddle gives Maisie a paper listing the pleasures she will have at her mother's house, and Maisie clutches it in her fist. When the mother arrives in a carriage, Moddle yells at the father. While holding Maisie, the father threatens Moddle and gives Maisie a message to deliver. In the carriage, Maisie's mother asks if her father sent a message. Maisie reports, "He said I was to tell you, from him... that you're a nasty horrid pig!"

[Original]

The child was provided for, but the new arrangement was inevitably confounding to a young intelligence intensely aware that something had happened which must matter a good deal and looking anxiously out for the effects of so great a cause. It was to be the fate of this patient little girl to see much more than she at first understood, but also even at first to understand much more than any little girl, however patient, had perhaps ever understood before. Only a drummer-boy in a ballad or a story could have been so in the thick of the fight. She was taken into the confidence of passions on which she fixed just the stare she might have had for images bounding across the wall in the slide of a magic-lantern.

Translation

The child was taken care of, but the new situation was inevitably confusing to a young mind, keenly aware that something significant had occurred. She anxiously awaited the consequences of such a major event. It would be this patient little girl's destiny to witness far more than she initially comprehended, but also, even from the beginning, to understand more than any little girl, no matter how patient, perhaps ever had before. Only a drummer boy in a ballad or a story could have been so deeply involved in the conflict. She was made privy to passions that she regarded with the same unwavering gaze she might have given to the images leaping across the wall in a magic lantern show.

[Original]

Her little world was phantasmagoric—strange shadows dancing on a sheet. It was as if the whole performance had been given for her—a mite of a half-scared infant in a great dim theatre. She was in short introduced to life with a liberality in which the selfishness of others found its account, and there was nothing to avert the sacrifice but the modesty of her youth. Her first term was with her father, who spared her only in not letting her have the wild letters addressed to her by her mother: he confined himself to holding them up at her and shaking them, while he showed his teeth, and then amusing her by the way he chucked them, across the room, bang into the fire.

Translation

Her world was a phantasmagoria—strange shadows danced on a sheet. It was as if the whole performance was for her—a tiny, half-scared infant in a vast, dim theater. She was, in short, introduced to life with a generosity that served the selfishness of others, and nothing could prevent the sacrifice except for the modesty of her youth. Her first term was with her father, who spared her only by not allowing her to have the frantic letters addressed to her by her mother: he limited himself to holding them up and shaking them at her while showing his teeth, and then amusing her by chucking them across the room, bang, into the fire.

[Original]

Even at that moment, however, she had a scared anticipation of fatigue, a guilty sense of not rising to the occasion, feeling the charm of the violence with which the stiff unopened envelopes, whose big monograms—Ida bristled with monograms—she would have liked to see, were made to whizz, like dangerous missiles, through the air. The greatest effect of the great cause was her own greater importance, chiefly revealed to her in the larger freedom with which she was handled, pulled hither and thither and kissed, and the proportionately greater niceness she was obliged to show. Her features had somehow become prominent; they were so perpetually nipped by the gentlemen who came to see her father and the smoke of whose cigarettes went into her face. Some of these gentlemen made her strike matches and light their cigarettes; others, holding her on knees violently jolted, pinched the calves of her legs till she shrieked—her shriek was much admired—and reproached them with being toothpicks.

Translation

Even at that moment, she was already anticipating exhaustion, a guilty feeling of not measuring up. She felt the allure of the violence with which the rigid, unopened envelopes—covered in monograms, Ida bristled with monograms—were flung through the air like dangerous projectiles. The main outcome of this grand scheme was her own increased significance, primarily revealed by the greater latitude she was given, being dragged this way and that, kissed, and the correspondingly greater display of niceness she was required to offer. Her features had somehow become pronounced; they were constantly pinched by the men who visited her father, their cigarette smoke blowing in her face. Some of these men made her strike matches and light their cigarettes; others, holding her on their violently bouncing knees, would pinch the calves of her legs until she shrieked—her shriek was much admired—and called them toothpicks.

[Original]

The word stuck in her mind and contributed to her feeling from this time that she was deficient in something that would meet the general desire. She found out what it was: it was a congenital tendency to the production of a substance to which Moddle, her nurse, gave a short ugly name, a name painfully associated at dinner with the part of the joint that she didn't like. She had left behind her the time when she had no desires to meet, none at least save Moddle's, who, in Kensington Gardens, was always on the bench when she came back to see if she had been playing too far. Moddle's desire was merely that she shouldn't do that, and she met it so easily that the only spots in that long brightness were the moments of her wondering what would become of her if, on her rushing back, there should be no Moddle on the bench.

Translation

The word remained lodged in her thoughts, and from then on, she began to feel as though she lacked something that everyone else seemed to want. She figured out what it was: a natural predisposition to produce a certain substance, which her nurse, Moddle, called by a short, unpleasant name. That name was unpleasantly linked, at dinner, to the part of the meat she disliked. She'd outgrown the phase when she had no desires to fulfill, save perhaps Moddle's, who always waited on the park bench in Kensington Gardens, checking to see if she'd wandered off too far. Moddle simply wanted her to stay close, a wish she granted so easily that the only shadows in that otherwise bright period were the moments when she worried what would happen if, upon returning, Moddle wasn't on the bench.

[Original]

They still went to the Gardens, but there was a difference even there; she was impelled perpetually to look at the legs of other children and ask her nurse if they were toothpicks. Moddle was terribly truthful; she always said: "Oh my dear, you'll not find such another pair as your own." It seemed to have to do with something else that Moddle often said: "You feel the strain—that's where it is; and you'll feel it still worse, you know." Thus from the first Maisie not only felt it, but knew she felt it. A part of it was the consequence of her father's telling her he felt it too, and telling Moddle, in her presence, that she must make a point of driving that home.

Translation

They still went to the Gardens, but even there, something had changed. She was compelled to constantly examine other children's legs, asking her nurse if they were like toothpicks. Moddle was brutally honest. She would always say, "Oh my dear, you'll never find legs like your own." It seemed to be related to something else Moddle often said: "You feel the strain—that's the problem; and you'll feel it even worse, you know." So, from the beginning, Maisie not only felt it, but knew she felt it. Part of it was due to her father telling her he felt it too, and telling Moddle, in her presence, that she must make sure to emphasize that point.

[Original]

She was familiar, at the age of six, with the fact that everything had been changed on her account, everything ordered to enable him to give himself up to her. She was to remember always the words in which Moddle impressed upon her that he did so give himself: "Your papa wishes you never to forget, you know, that he has been dreadfully put about." If the skin on Moddle's face had to Maisie the air of being unduly, almost painfully, stretched, it never presented that appearance so much as when she uttered, as she often had occasion to utter, such words. The child wondered if they didn't make it hurt more than usual; but it was only after some time that she was able to attach to the picture of her father's sufferings, and more particularly to her nurse's manner about them, the meaning for which these things had waited. By the time she had grown sharper, as the gentlemen who had criticised her calves used to say, she found in her mind a collection of images and echoes to which meanings were attachable—images and echoes kept for her in the childish dusk, the dim closet, the high drawers, like games she wasn't yet big enough to play.

Translation

At six years old, she understood that everything had been altered for her sake, that everything was arranged to allow him to devote himself to her. She was always to remember the words Moddle used to emphasize this: "Your papa wants you to never forget, you know, that he's been terribly inconvenienced." If the skin on Moddle's face seemed to Maisie unnaturally, almost painfully, stretched, it was never more so than when she spoke those words, as she often did. The child wondered if those words didn't cause her extra pain, but it was only later that she was able to understand the meaning behind the image of her father's suffering, and especially her nurse's demeanor surrounding it. By the time she had become more astute, as the men who criticized her legs would say, she found in her mind a collection of images and echoes to which meanings could be attached—images and echoes held for her in the childish shadows, the dim closet, the high drawers, like games she wasn't yet old enough to play.

[Original]

The great strain meanwhile was that of carrying by the right end the things her father said about her mother—things mostly indeed that Moddle, on a glimpse of them, as if they had been complicated toys or difficult books, took out of her hands and put away in the closet. A wonderful assortment of objects of this kind she was to discover there later, all tumbled up too with the things, shuffled into the same receptacle, that her mother had said about her father. She had the knowledge that on a certain occasion which every day brought nearer her mother would be at the door to take her away, and this would have darkened all the days if the ingenious Moddle hadn't written on a paper in very big easy words ever so many pleasures that she would enjoy at the other house. These promises ranged from "a mother's fond love" to "a nice poached egg to your tea," and took by the way the prospect of sitting up ever so late to see the lady in question dressed, in silks and velvets and diamonds and pearls, to go out: so that it was a real support to Maisie, at the supreme hour, to feel how, by Moddle's direction, the paper was thrust away in her pocket and there clenched in her fist.

Translation

The great challenge, in the meantime, was managing the things her father said about her mother, things that Moddle, upon seeing them, would snatch from her as if they were complex toys or difficult books, and then stow away in the closet. Later, she would discover a remarkable collection of such objects there, all jumbled together with the things her mother had said about her father, all mixed up in the same place. She knew that a certain day, drawing ever closer, her mother would be at the door to take her away, and this would have cast a pall over all her days had not the ingenious Moddle written on a piece of paper, in large, simple letters, all sorts of pleasures she would enjoy at the other house. These promises included "a mother's fond love" and "a nice poached egg to your tea," and along the way, the prospect of staying up late to see the woman in question dressed in silks and velvets and diamonds and pearls, ready to go out. Therefore, at the crucial moment, it was a real comfort to Maisie to feel how, under Moddle's instruction, the paper was shoved into her pocket and clenched in her fist.

[Original]

The supreme hour was to furnish her with a vivid reminiscence, that of a strange outbreak in the drawing-room on the part of Moddle, who, in reply to something her father had just said, cried aloud: "You ought to be perfectly ashamed of yourself—you ought to blush, sir, for the way you go on!" The carriage, with her mother in it, was at the door; a gentleman who was there, who was always there, laughed out very loud; her father, who had her in his arms, said to Moddle: "My dear woman, I'll settle you presently!"—after which he repeated, showing his teeth more than ever at Maisie while he hugged her, the words for which her nurse had taken him up. Maisie was not at the moment so fully conscious of them as of the wonder of Moddle's sudden disrespect and crimson face; but she was able to produce them in the course of five minutes when, in the carriage, her mother, all kisses, ribbons, eyes, arms, strange sounds and sweet smells, said to her: "And did your beastly papa, my precious angel, send any message to your own loving mamma?" Then it was that she found the words spoken by her beastly papa to be, after all, in her little bewildered ears, from which, at her mother's appeal, they passed, in her clear shrill voice, straight to her little innocent lips. "He said I was to tell you, from him," she faithfully reported, "that you're a nasty horrid pig!"

Translation

The defining moment was to give her a striking memory: a strange outburst in the drawing-room from Moddle, who, in response to something her father had just said, cried out, "You should be ashamed of yourself—you ought to blush, sir, for the way you behave!" The carriage, with her mother inside, was at the door. A gentleman who was always present laughed very loudly. Her father, who held her in his arms, said to Moddle, "My dear woman, I'll deal with you later!"—after which he repeated the words her nurse had scolded him for, showing his teeth more than ever at Maisie as he hugged her. Maisie wasn't as aware of the words themselves as she was of the wonder of Moddle's sudden disrespect and crimson face. But she was able to recall them within five minutes. In the carriage, her mother, all kisses, ribbons, eyes, arms, strange sounds, and sweet smells, said to her, "And did your beastly papa, my precious angel, send any message to your own loving mamma?" That's when she found the words her beastly papa had said were, after all, in her little, bewildered ears, and from which, at her mother's request, they passed, in her clear, shrill voice, straight to her little, innocent lips. "He said I was to tell you, from him," she reported faithfully, "that you're a nasty horrid pig!"

Chapter II

Show Chapter Summary
For a couple of years, a young girl's parents use her to carry insults between them. Associates of the parents notice but do nothing. The parents come to believe she is stupid. The girl realizes her role as a messenger and decides to stop repeating what she is told. As a result, she is called an idiot and dull by her parents. The girl, Maisie, gets a new governess, Miss Overmore, who replaces a former nurse named Moddle. Maisie's mother hires Miss Overmore. One day, Maisie asks Miss Overmore if she should tell her father a message from her mother: "that he lies and he knows he lies." Miss Overmore turns red, laughs, and pricks her hand with a needle. With her eyes, she communicates that she is afraid of Maisie's mother but also feels loyalty to Maisie's father. This reminds Maisie of a time when she and Miss Overmore met her father in a park. He spoke to Miss Overmore and asked for her help to save his daughter. Afterward, Miss Overmore asked Maisie not to mention the meeting to her mother, and Maisie agreed.

[Original]

In that lively sense of the immediate which is the very air of a child's mind the past, on each occasion, became for her as indistinct as the future: she surrendered herself to the actual with a good faith that might have been touching to either parent. Crudely as they had calculated they were at first justified by the event: she was the little feathered shuttlecock they could fiercely keep flying between them. The evil they had the gift of thinking or pretending to think of each other they poured into her little gravely-gazing soul as into a boundless receptacle, and each of them had doubtless the best conscience in the world as to the duty of teaching her the stern truth that should be her safeguard against the other. She was at the age for which all stories are true and all conceptions are stories.

Translation

In the vibrant immediacy that defines a child's mind, the past became as blurred as the future with each moment. She gave herself over to the present with a sincerity that might have moved either parent. Though their planning was crude, they were initially vindicated by the outcome: she was the tiny, feathered shuttlecock they could fiercely keep aloft between them. The malice they were capable of imagining or feigning towards each other, they poured into her small, gravely-observing soul, as if into a boundless vessel. Each of them, without a doubt, possessed the purest conscience in the world, believing it their duty to teach her the harsh truths that would protect her from the other. She was at the age when all narratives are believed, and all understandings are seen as stories.

[Original]

The actual was the absolute, the present alone was vivid. The objurgation for instance launched in the carriage by her mother after she had at her father's bidding punctually performed was a missive that dropped into her memory with the dry rattle of a letter falling into a pillar-box. Like the letter it was, as part of the contents of a well-stuffed post-bag, delivered in due course at the right address. In the presence of these overflowings, after they had continued for a couple of years, the associates of either party sometimes felt that something should be done for what they called "the real good, don't you know?" of the child.

Translation

The real was absolute; only the present was alive. The scolding, for instance, that her mother launched in the carriage after she'd dutifully performed at her father's request was a message that landed in her memory with the dry clatter of a letter dropping into a mailbox. Like the letter, it was part of the contents of a stuffed postbag, delivered in due course to the right address. After these tirades had continued for a couple of years, the associates of either parent sometimes felt that something should be done for what they called “the real good, don’t you know?” of the child.

[Original]

The only thing done, however, in general, took place when it was sighingly remarked that she fortunately wasn't all the year round where she happened to be at the awkward moment, and that, furthermore, either from extreme cunning or from extreme stupidity, she appeared not to take things in. The theory of her stupidity, eventually embraced by her parents, corresponded with a great date in her small still life: the complete vision, private but final, of the strange office she filled. It was literally a moral revolution and accomplished in the depths of her nature. The stiff dolls on the dusky shelves began to move their arms and legs; old forms and phrases began to have a sense that frightened her.

Translation

The only action taken, however, was a general sigh, along with the observation that she wasn't always stuck where she happened to be at a bad moment, and that, moreover, whether out of extreme cleverness or extreme stupidity, she didn't seem to understand things. The theory that she was stupid, which her parents eventually adopted, aligned with a pivotal moment in her private, still existence: the complete, private, and final understanding of the strange role she played. It was, quite literally, a moral revolution, taking place deep within her. The stiff dolls on the dusty shelves began to move their arms and legs; old ideas and phrases began to take on a meaning that frightened her.

[Original]

She had a new feeling, the feeling of danger; on which a new remedy rose to meet it, the idea of an inner self or, in other words, of concealment. She puzzled out with imperfect signs, but with a prodigious spirit, that she had been a centre of hatred and a messenger of insult, and that everything was bad because she had been employed to make it so. Her parted lips locked themselves with the determination to be employed no longer. She would forget everything, she would repeat nothing, and when, as a tribute to the successful application of her system, she began to be called a little idiot, she tasted a pleasure new and keen.

Translation

She felt something new: danger. In response, a solution arose: the idea of an inner self, or, in other words, concealment. Though she deciphered the signs imperfectly, she did so with great energy, understanding that she had been a focus of hatred and a harbinger of insult, that everything was wrong because she had been used to make it so. Her parted lips closed, determined to be used no longer. She would forget everything, repeat nothing, and when, as a result of her success, she began to be called a little idiot, she tasted a new and intense pleasure.

[Original]

When therefore, as she grew older, her parents in turn announced before her that she had grown shockingly dull, it was not from any real contraction of her little stream of life. She spoiled their fun, but she practically added to her own. She saw more and more; she saw too much. It was Miss Overmore, her first governess, who on a momentous occasion had sown the seeds of secrecy; sown them not by anything she said, but by a mere roll of those fine eyes which Maisie already admired.

Translation

Therefore, as she aged, when her parents announced that she'd become shockingly dull, it wasn't because her inner life had shrunk. She ruined their amusement, but she practically expanded her own. She saw more and more; she saw too much. It was Miss Overmore, her first governess, who, on a momentous occasion, had planted the seeds of secrecy; she'd done so not by saying anything, but by merely rolling those fine eyes that Maisie already admired.

[Original]

Moddle had become at this time, after alternations of residence of which the child had no clear record, an image faintly embalmed in the remembrance of hungry disappearances from the nursery and distressful lapses in the alphabet, sad embarrassments, in particular, when invited to recognise something her nurse described as "the important letter haitch." Miss Overmore, however hungry, never disappeared: this marked her somehow as of higher rank, and the character was confirmed by a prettiness that Maisie supposed to be extraordinary. Mrs. Farange had described her as almost too pretty, and some one had asked what that mattered so long as Beale wasn't there. "Beale or no Beale," Maisie had heard her mother reply, "I take her because she's a lady and yet awfully poor.

Translation

At this time, after a series of moves that the child couldn't quite remember, Moddle had become a hazy figure in Maisie's memory. She was associated with hungry departures from the nursery, distressing failures in learning the alphabet, and embarrassing moments, particularly when asked to identify what her nurse called "the important letter haitch." Miss Overmore, however hungry, never disappeared, which seemed to put her in a higher class. This was also because she was pretty, in Maisie's opinion, extraordinarily so. Mrs. Farange had said she was almost too pretty, and someone had asked what that mattered as long as Beale wasn't around. "Beale or no Beale," Maisie had heard her mother reply, "I take her because she's a lady and yet awfully poor."

[Original]

Rather nice people, but there are seven sisters at home. What do people mean?" Maisie didn't know what people meant, but she knew very soon all the names of all the sisters; she could say them off better than she could say the multiplication-table. She privately wondered moreover, though she never asked, about the awful poverty, of which her companion also never spoke.

Translation

Rather nice people, but they have seven sisters at home. What do people mean?" Maisie didn't know what people meant, but she very quickly learned all the sisters' names; she could recite them better than the multiplication tables. Privately, and though she never asked, she wondered about the awful poverty, which her companion also never mentioned.

[Original]

Food at any rate came up by mysterious laws; Miss Overmore never, like Moddle, had on an apron, and when she ate she held her fork with her little finger curled out. The child, who watched her at many moments, watched her particularly at that one. "I think you're lovely," she often said to her; even mamma, who was lovely too, had not such a pretty way with the fork. Maisie associated this showier presence with her now being "big," knowing of course that nursery-governesses were only for little girls who were not, as she said, "really" little.

Translation

Food, at any rate, arrived as if by magic. Miss Overmore never wore an apron, unlike Moddle. When she ate, she held her fork with her pinky finger extended. The child, who often observed her, focused intently on this particular gesture. "I think you're lovely," she frequently told her. Even her mother, who was also lovely, didn't use her fork so prettily. Maisie connected this more elegant demeanor with her now being "big," understanding that nursery governesses were only for little girls who, as she put it, weren't "really" little.

[Original]

She vaguely knew, further, somehow, that the future was still bigger than she, and that a part of what made it so was the number of governesses lurking in it and ready to dart out. Everything that had happened when she was really little was dormant, everything but the positive certitude, bequeathed from afar by Moddle, that the natural way for a child to have her parents was separate and successive, like her mutton and her pudding or her bath and her nap. "Does he know he lies?"—that was what she had vivaciously asked Miss Overmore on the occasion which was so suddenly to lead to a change in her life. "Does he know—" Miss Overmore stared; she had a stocking pulled over her hand and was pricking at it with a needle which she poised in the act.

Translation

She had a vague understanding that the future was still larger than she was, and part of what made it so was the number of governesses lurking in it, ready to appear at any moment. Everything that had happened when she was very small was dormant, except for the certainty, passed on by Moddle, that the natural way for a child to have parents was separately and one after another, like her mutton and her pudding or her bath and her nap. [Original]

Her task was homely, but her movement, like all her movements, graceful. "Why papa." "That he 'lies'?" "That's what mamma says I'm to tell him—'that he lies and he knows he lies.'" Miss Overmore turned very red, though she laughed out till her head fell back; then she pricked again at her muffled hand so hard that Maisie wondered how she could bear it.

Translation

Her task was ordinary, but her movements, as always, were graceful. “Why, Papa.” “That he ‘lies’?” “That’s what Mama wants me to tell him—‘that he lies and he knows he lies.’” Miss Overmore turned very red, though she laughed until her head fell back; then she pricked again at her covered hand so hard that Maisie wondered how she could stand it.

[Original]

"Am I to tell him?" the child went on. It was then that her companion addressed her in the unmistakeable language of a pair of eyes of deep dark grey. Chapter III

Chapter IV

Show Chapter Summary
Maisie's mother arrives in a carriage and drives her away in silence to a new home where an old woman, Mrs. Wix, is waiting on the doorstep. The mother tells Mrs. Wix to take the child and gives Maisie a push toward her. Mrs. Wix takes charge of Maisie. She tells Maisie about her own deceased daughter, Clara Matilda, who was killed in an accident. Mrs. Wix tells Maisie to think of Clara Matilda as her "little dead sister," a secret they must keep. Maisie learns all the details of Clara Matilda's short life. One day, Mrs. Wix accompanies Maisie to a drawing-room and leaves her there. Maisie overhears a lady tell another that her mother hired Mrs. Wix for very low pay. Mrs. Wix takes Maisie to visit Clara Matilda's grave. During their time together, Mrs. Wix avoids many school subjects, instead telling Maisie stories from novels she has read and from her own life, though she never mentions her late husband.

[Original]

All this led her on, but it brought on her fate as well, the day when her mother would be at the door in the carriage in which Maisie now rode on no occasions but these. There was no question at present of Miss Overmore's going back with her: it was universally recognised that her quarrel with Mrs. Farange was much too acute. The child felt it from the first; there was no hugging nor exclaiming as that lady drove her away—there was only a frightening silence, unenlivened even by the invidious enquiries of former years, which culminated, according to its stern nature, in a still more frightening old woman, a figure awaiting her on the very doorstep.

Maisie could play more pieces than Mrs. Wix, who was plainly embarrassed by her houses and trees, only able to depict the smoke billowing from chimneys with the help of a sooty forefinger, a technique of questionable artistic merit. [Original]

A child, Maisie, parts from Mrs. Wix with a silent, intense hug. Maisie's father stands over them, holding an open watch and grinning, while Miss Overmore waits in a brougham outside. Maisie's education is neglected, and she spends her time with an under-housemaid named Susan Ash. The situation, however, took a turn when, on another of her returns, side by side with Susan, utterly exhausted from the pursuit of exercise marked by excessive loitering, she encountered another emotion.

[Original]

She on this occasion learnt at the door that her instant attendance was requested in the drawing-room. Crossing the threshold in a cloud of shame she discerned through the blur Mrs. Beale seated there with a gentleman who immediately drew the pain from her predicament by rising before her as the original of the photograph of Sir Claude. She felt the moment she looked at him that he was by far the most shining presence that had ever made her gape, and her pleasure in seeing him, in knowing that he took hold of her and kissed her, as quickly throbbed into a strange shy pride in him, a perception of his making up for her fallen state, for Susan's public nudges, which quite bruised her, and for all the lessons that, in the dead schoolroom, where at times she was almost afraid to stay alone, she was bored with not having.

Translation

She sensed he somehow made up for her diminished standing, for the public mockery of Susan's nudges, which had stung her, and for all the lessons she was bored of not having in the silent, often frightening schoolroom.

Chapter IX

Show Chapter Summary
Mrs. Wix arrives at the home of Maisie's mother. For the first three days, Maisie's mother refuses to see her. During this time, Sir Claude visits Maisie in the schoolroom, explaining that her mother is angry because he arranged for Maisie to come to her house without her knowledge, using it as a way to meet Mrs. Beale. He asks Maisie not to tell her mother what Mrs. Beale said to him. He teases Mrs. Wix and reminds Maisie to remain silent. Mrs. Wix tells Maisie that her mother is passionately in love. Maisie is then summoned to see her mother, Ida, who now has coppery red hair. Ida questions Maisie about what happened between Sir Claude and Mrs. Beale. Maisie pretends to be stupid to avoid answering, and her mother calls her not amusing. After the meeting, Maisie tells Mrs. Wix that her mother said her duty would be done. In the following weeks, Maisie's mother often does not see her for days. Maisie spends her time with Mrs. Wix and Sir Claude. Sir Claude gives gifts to Mrs. Wix (a five-pound note, a book, an umbrella) and to Maisie (chocolates, books, a coat, games, a frame). He takes them to the pantomime and walks with them publicly. Maisie and Mrs. Wix spend their evenings talking about him, unable to understand the rules for the games he bought. Maisie asks Mrs. Wix if she is in love with Sir Claude, and Mrs. Wix says she is. A few days later, Mrs. Wix asks Maisie the same question, and Maisie says she is too. Later, for long periods, Sir Claude and Ida are away from the house, sometimes together and sometimes apart, leaving Maisie and Mrs. Wix alone to forage for food. During one of these times, Mrs. Wix tells Maisie that Mrs. Beale has been trying to see her, that her mother resents it, and that Sir Claude has supported Mrs. Beale in the matter. The text flashes back to an earlier conversation where Maisie, alone with Sir Claude, asked him if he was still in communication with Mrs. Beale.

[Original]

The idea of what she was to make up and the prodigious total it came to were kept well before Maisie at her mother's. These things were the constant occupation of Mrs. Wix, who arrived there by the back stairs, but in tears of joy, the day after her own arrival. The process of making up, as to which the good lady had an immense deal to say, took, through its successive phases, so long that it heralded a term at least equal to the child's last stretch with her father.

Translation

Maisie's mother made sure she kept the details of what she was supposed to fabricate, and the staggering sum it all added up to, at the forefront of her mind. This was the constant focus of Mrs. Wix, who arrived by the back stairs, weeping tears of happiness the day after she got there. The process of making things up, about which the kind woman had a great deal to say, took so long in its various stages that it promised to last at least as long as the child's last period of time with her father.

[Original]

This, however, was a fuller and richer time: it bounded along to the tune of Mrs. Wix's constant insistence on the energy they must both put forth. There was a fine intensity in the way the child agreed with her that under Mrs. Beale and Susan Ash she had learned nothing whatever; the wildness of the rescued castaway was one of the forces that would henceforth make for a career of conquest.

Translation

There was a potent conviction in the child’s agreement that she had learned absolutely nothing from Mrs. Beale and Susan Ash; the untamed nature of a survivor was one of the elements that would from then on enable a successful future.

[Original]

The year therefore rounded itself as a receptacle of retarded knowledge—a cup brimming over with the sense that now at least she was learning. Mrs. Wix fed this sense from the stores of her conversation and with the immense bustle of her reminder that they must cull the fleeting hour. They were surrounded with subjects they must take at a rush and perpetually getting into the attitude of triumphant attack.

Translation

They were surrounded by subjects they had to grasp quickly, perpetually adopting the posture of a triumphant assault.

It was revealed through Sir Claude's candid confession that her ladyship hadn't known about his visit to her late husband's house. She hadn't known that he had used the man's daughter as a way to become acquainted with the terrible woman who lived there. God knows she wanted her child back and had made her own plans to get her. What she couldn't forgive, at least for the moment, was such a meddling, underhanded way of accomplishing the transfer. Maisie bore the brunt of this resentment more than even Mrs. Wix.

[Original]

Wix's confidential ingenuity could lighten for her, especially as Sir Claude himself was not at all ingenious, though indeed on the other hand he was not at all crushed. He was amused and intermittent and at moments most startling; he impressed on his young companion, with a frankness that agitated her much more than he seemed to guess, that he depended on her not letting her mother, when she should see her, get anything out of her about anything Mrs. Beale might have said to him. He came in and out; he professed, in joke, to take tremendous precautions; he showed a positive disposition to romp.

Translation

Mrs. Wix's quiet cleverness could be a relief for Maisie, particularly since Sir Claude wasn't clever at all, though on the other hand, he wasn't downcast either. He was entertained and unpredictable, and at times, quite shocking. He made it clear to his young friend, with a candor that upset her far more than he realized, that he was counting on her to prevent her mother from extracting any information from her regarding anything Mrs. Beale might have said to him. He came and went as he pleased; he pretended, jokingly, to take extreme precautions; he showed a definite tendency to be playful.

[Original]

He chaffed Mrs. Wix till she was purple with the pleasure of it, and reminded Maisie of the reticence he expected of her till she set her teeth like an Indian captive. Her lessons these first days and indeed for long after seemed to be all about Sir Claude, and yet she never really mentioned to Mrs. Wix that she was prepared, under his inspiring injunction, to be vainly tortured.

He teased Mrs. Wix until she blushed with delight, and reminded Maisie of the secrecy he demanded of her until she clenched her jaw like a prisoner. Her lessons during these initial days, and indeed for a long while afterwards, appeared to be entirely about Sir Claude. Yet she never actually told Mrs. Wix that she was ready, spurred by his encouraging instruction, to endure futile torment.

[Original]

This lady, however, had formulated the position of things with an acuteness that showed how little she needed to be coached. Her explanation of everything that seemed not quite pleasant—and if her own footing was perilous it met that danger as well—that her ladyship was passionately in love. Maisie accepted this hint with infinite awe and pressed upon it much when she was at last summoned into the presence of her mother. This lady, however, had understood the situation with a sharpness that revealed how little she needed guidance. They had been some time in the house together, and this demonstration came late. This picturesque parent showed literally a grander stature and a nobler presence, things which, with some others that might have been bewildering, were handsomely accounted for by the romantic state of her affections.

Show Chapter Summary
A man, Sir Claude, smokes a cigarette by the fire and remarks to a child, Maisie, about the room's sparse decorations. He then questions Maisie about Mrs. Beale, asking if she truly cares for the child and how her affection compares to that of Mrs. Wix. Maisie says Mrs. Beale loves her and will never give her up. She explains that Mrs. Beale does not write because of "mamma" and that Mrs. Wix dislikes Mrs. Beale but remains silent about it for Maisie's sake. Sir Claude tells Maisie he has not seen Mrs. Beale and cannot visit her because his wife (Maisie's mother) forbids it. He explains Mrs. Beale cannot visit them for the same reason. He tells Maisie he will support her. Maisie reminds him that Mrs. Beale believed Maisie had brought them together. Sir Claude laughs and agrees. Maisie asks if she is going back to Mrs. Beale, and Sir Claude says she will someday. Maisie points out she has also brought him and Mrs. Wix together, which he confirms. He jokingly suggests she bring him and her mother together but then says it is impossible. He reassures her that their own relationship is fine. When Maisie asks how she could ever leave him, Sir Claude suggests her mother might eventually leave him with Maisie. He adds this would be Mrs. Beale's chance to have Maisie back. Maisie asks if he will visit her at Mrs. Beale's, and he says he can. As Maisie presses him for a promise to visit often, Mrs. Wix enters the room. Later, Sir Claude resumes the conversation. He tells Maisie he can secretly visit her when she is with Mrs. Beale, but Mrs. Beale cannot visit their current home because Mrs. Wix would inform Maisie's mother. He clarifies that he and Mrs. Wix are allies on all matters except Mrs. Beale. Finally, he admits he is afraid of Maisie's mother.

Chapter XI

Show Chapter Summary
A lady makes visits during which she surveys the room, sometimes sitting and other times pacing. Her behavior toward her child, Maisie, alternates between ignoring her and hugging her. Sometimes she is accompanied by Sir Claude, and during these times she laughs freely. Later, the mother tells Maisie that she has handed over responsibility for her to Sir Claude. She says Sir Claude is not serious. Maisie cries to her governess, Mrs. Wix, about this. Maisie then talks with Sir Claude about her mother. One day, the mother, Sir Claude, Mrs. Wix, and Maisie are in a room together. The mother grabs Maisie, sobs, and accuses Sir Claude of turning the child against her. She then pushes Maisie across the room into Mrs. Wix's arms. Maisie sees Mrs. Wix and Sir Claude exchange a look. When Maisie later asks Mrs. Wix about the incident, Mrs. Wix calls it "her ladyship's game." In response, Sir Claude leaves for Paris alone. While he is away, the mother brings a man named Mr. Perriam to the schoolroom to meet Maisie and Mrs. Wix. After he leaves, Mrs. Wix tells Maisie that Mr. Perriam is very wealthy and that Sir Claude will not like his visits. Sir Claude returns from Paris, bringing a watercolor set for Maisie and a second umbrella for Mrs. Wix. He begins spending more time in the schoolroom with Maisie and Mrs. Wix. Maisie knows that he and Mrs. Wix have late-night talks. Mrs. Wix tells Maisie that they talk about getting Sir Claude into Parliament to save him from "awful misery."

[Original]

It must not be supposed that her ladyship's intermissions were not qualified by demonstrations of another order—triumphal entries and breathless pauses during which she seemed to take of everything in the room, from the state of the ceiling to that of her daughter's boot-toes, a survey that was rich in intentions. Sometimes she sat down and sometimes she surged about, but her attitude wore equally in either case the grand air of the practical. She found so much to deplore that she left a great deal to expect, and bristled so with calculation that she seemed to scatter remedies and pledges. Her visits were as good as an outfit; her manner, as Mrs.

Translation

It shouldn't be assumed that her ladyship's breaks weren't punctuated by displays of a different sort—triumphant pronouncements and moments of held breath during which she seemed to take in everything in the room, from the state of the ceiling to that of her daughter's boot-toes, a survey pregnant with significance. Sometimes she sat and sometimes she paced, but whether still or in motion, her bearing possessed equally the air of the pragmatist. She found so much to disapprove of that she left a great deal to anticipate, and bristled with such calculation that she seemed to scatter solutions and promises. Her visits were as good as a new wardrobe; her manner, as Mrs.

[Original]

Wix once said, as good as a pair of curtains; but she was a person addicted to extremes—sometimes barely speaking to her child and sometimes pressing this tender shoot to a bosom cut, as Mrs. Wix had also observed, remarkably low. She was always in a fearful hurry, and the lower the bosom was cut the more it was to be gathered she was wanted elsewhere. She usually broke in alone, but sometimes Sir Claude was with her, and during all the earlier period there was nothing on which these appearances had had so delightful a bearing as on the way her ladyship was, as Mrs.

Translation

Wix put it, "on the make." Her ladyship's style, her smile, the way she held her head—all were so charged with a secret that it was no good trying to figure it out. It was too late to wonder if she knew something. She was a woman who always knew, who always had known.

[Original]

Wix expressed it, under the spell. "But isn't she under it!" Maisie used in thoughtful but familiar reference to exclaim after Sir Claude had swept mamma away in peals of natural laughter. Not even in the old days of the convulsed ladies had she heard mamma laugh so freely as in these moments of conjugal surrender, to the gaiety of which even a little girl could see she had at last a right—a little girl whose thoughtfulness was now all happy selfish meditation on good omens and future fun. Unaccompanied, in subsequent hours, and with an effect of changing to meet a change, Ida took a tone superficially disconcerting and abrupt—the tone of having, at an immense cost, made over everything to Sir Claude and wishing others to know that if everything wasn't right it was because Sir Claude was so dreadfully vague.

Translation

Wix said it, completely captivated. "But doesn't she seem to be!" Maisie exclaimed thoughtfully, but with a knowing air, after Sir Claude had carried her mother away with infectious laughter. Even in the old days, when the ladies were prone to fits of hysteria, Maisie hadn't heard her mother laugh so freely as she did during those moments of marital bliss. Even a little girl could see that her mother had finally earned the right to such joy—a little girl whose thoughtfulness was now consumed by happy, selfish thoughts about good omens and future fun. Later, alone, and seeming to shift to accommodate a change, Ida adopted a tone that was superficially unsettling and abrupt—the tone of someone who, at a tremendous cost, had yielded everything to Sir Claude, and wanted others to know that if everything wasn't perfect, it was because Sir Claude was so impossibly vague.

[Original]

"He has made from the first such a row about you," she said on one occasion to Maisie, "that I've told him to do for you himself and try how he likes it—see? I've washed my hands of you; I've made you over to him; and if you're discontented it's on him, please, you'll come down. So don't haul poor me up—I assure you I've worries enough." One of these, visibly, was that the spell rejoiced in by the schoolroom fire was already in danger of breaking; another was that she was finally forced to make no secret of her husband's unfitness for real responsibilities. The day came indeed when her breathless auditors learnt from her in bewilderment that what ailed him was that he was, alas, simply not serious.

Translation

"He's been making such a fuss about you from the start," she said to Maisie once, "that I've told him to take care of you himself and see how he likes it—understand? I've washed my hands of you; I've handed you over to him; and if you're unhappy, it's on him, please, you'll come down. So don't drag me into it—I assure you I have enough troubles." One of these, clearly, was that the special atmosphere enjoyed by the fireside in the schoolroom was already in danger of fading; another was that she was finally forced to admit, without hiding it, that her husband was incapable of handling real responsibilities. The day came when her listeners, breathless with confusion, heard from her that what was wrong with him was, alas, that he was simply not serious.

[Original]

That had been proper to every one's station that she had yet encountered save poor Mrs. Wix's own, and the particular merit of Sir Claude had seemed precisely that he was different from every one.

Translation

Maisie cried on Mrs. Wix's shoulder after learning that Sir Claude was a playboy; considering, furthermore, that her governess only half-addressed the situation, offering in the following days that his carelessness and freedom were appropriate for his "station." That had been appropriate for everyone's station she'd known, except poor Mrs. Wix's, and the specific appeal of Sir Claude had seemed precisely that he was unlike everyone else.

[Original]

She talked with him, however, as time went on, very freely about her mother; being with him, in this relation, wholly without the fear that had kept her silent before her father—the fear of bearing tales and making bad things worse. He appeared to accept the idea that he had taken her over and made her, as he said, his particular lark; he quite agreed also that he was an awful fraud and an idle beast and a sorry dunce. And he never said a word to her against her mother—he only remained dumb and discouraged in the face of her ladyship's own overtopping earnestness. There were occasions when he even spoke as if he had wrenched his little charge from the arms of a parent who had fought for her tooth and nail.

Translation

As time passed, she spoke to him very openly about her mother. When she was with him, she felt none of the fear that had kept her from speaking to her father—the fear of tattling and making things worse. He seemed to accept the idea that he had taken her over and made her, as he put it, his special amusement. He also readily agreed that he was a terrible fake, a lazy fool, and a complete idiot. And he never spoke against her mother. He only remained silent and disheartened when faced with her ladyship's overbearing intensity. There were times when he even spoke as if he had stolen his little protégé from a parent who had fought tooth and nail to keep her.

[Original]

This was the very moral of a scene that flashed into vividness one day when the four happened to meet without company in the drawing-room and Maisie found herself clutched to her mother's breast and passionately sobbed and shrieked over, made the subject of a demonstration evidently sequent to some sharp passage just enacted. The connexion required that while she almost cradled the child in her arms Ida should speak of her as hideously, as fatally estranged, and should rail at Sir Claude as the cruel author of the outrage. "He has taken you from me," she cried; "he has set you against me, and you've been won away and your horrid little mind has been poisoned! You've gone over to him, you've given yourself up to side against me and hate me.

Chapter XII

Show Chapter Summary
Mrs. Wix tells Maisie that her mother, Ida, is angry that Maisie’s father has not sent for her. Mrs. Wix then reveals that Ida had a terrible argument with her and told her to leave the house immediately. Mrs. Wix says she refuses to leave unless forced by the police and confesses her fears to Maisie. She explains that the tension is greatest between Ida and Sir Claude. After Maisie guesses the wrong man, Mrs. Wix clarifies that Sir Claude is angry with Ida about "someone else." At the mention of another name, Mrs. Wix becomes agitated, and she and Maisie sob in each other's arms. Mrs. Wix then recounts how Ida insulted her, calling her a spy and a hypocrite. The next day, Sir Claude visits for tea. Mrs. Wix proposes that he leave the house and find a lodging to share with her and Maisie. Sir Claude protests, citing his responsibility to his wife, but Mrs. Wix warns him that Ida may leave him first. She describes Ida’s abusive language toward her and says Ida has instructed the servants not to wait on her. Sir Claude worries how it will look if he leaves his wife, but Mrs. Wix insists it will "save" him from another "real bad" woman. Sir Claude takes Maisie into his arms and promises he will never forsake her. Maisie cries silently on his shoulder, and Mrs. Wix sobs aloud. In the following days, Sir Claude intervenes to prevent Ida from forcibly ejecting Mrs. Wix. He sends a large cake for Maisie and Mrs. Wix and begins taking Maisie on frequent outings across London. During these absences, Mrs. Wix endures Ida's insults at home. Sir Claude tells Maisie that Ida despises him for looking after her and accuses him of being afraid of her father. Meanwhile, Ida’s weekly weekend absences from London grow longer.

They dropped, under incontrollable impulses, into shops that they agreed were too big, to look at things that they agreed were too small, and it was during these hours that Mrs. Wix, alone at home, but a subject of regretful reference as they pulled off their gloves for refreshment, subsequently described herself as least sheltered from the blows her ladyship had achieved such ingenuity in dealing. There was by this time no pretence on the part of any one of denying it to be fortunate that her ladyship habitually left London every Saturday and was more and more disposed to a return late in the week.

Translation

They impulsively wandered into shops they both deemed too large, to examine things they both found too small, and it was during these hours that Mrs. Wix, alone at home but a subject of mournful discussion as they removed their gloves for a break, would later characterize herself as the least protected from the attacks her ladyship had become so skilled at delivering. She continually reiterated that she wouldn't have minded having her "accomplishments" ridiculed or her understanding of every subject dismissed, if she hadn't been labeled as having a "low" character and manner. By this point, no one pretended to deny that it was fortunate her ladyship habitually left London every Saturday and was increasingly inclined to return late in the week.

[Original]

It was almost equally public that she regarded as a preposterous "pose," and indeed as a direct insult to herself, her husband's attitude of staying behind to look after a child for whom the most elaborate provision had been made. If there was a type Ida despised, Sir Claude communicated to Maisie, it was the man who pottered about town of a Sunday; and he also mentioned how often she had declared to him that if he had a grain of spirit he would be ashamed to accept a menial position about Mr. Farange's daughter. It was her ladyship's contention that he was in craven fear of his predecessor—otherwise he would recognise it as an obligation of plain decency to protect his wife against the outrage of that person's barefaced attempt to swindle her.

Translation

It was almost equally well-known that she considered her husband's habit of staying behind to care for a child—for whom the most extensive arrangements had been made—a preposterous "pose," and a direct insult to herself. If there was a type Ida despised, Sir Claude confided in Maisie, it was the man who idled about town on a Sunday. [Original]

The swindle was that Mr. Farange put upon her the whole intolerable burden; "and even when I pay for you myself," Sir Claude averred to his young friend, "she accuses me the more of truckling and grovelling." It was Mrs. Wix's conviction, they both knew, arrived at on independent grounds, that Ida's weekly excursions were feelers for a more considerable absence. If she came back later each week the week would be sure to arrive when she wouldn't come back at all.

Translation

The trick was that Mr. Farange placed the entire impossible weight on her; "and even when I pay for you myself," Sir Claude declared to his young friend, "she accuses me even more of pandering and crawling." Both of them knew that Mrs. Wix was convinced, based on her own reasoning, that Ida's weekly outings were just trial runs for a longer absence. [Original]

This appearance had of course much to do with Mrs. Wix's actual valour. Could they but hold out long enough the snug little home with Sir Claude would find itself informally established.

Translation

This was, of course, mostly due to Mrs. Wix's true courage. If they could only hold on long enough, the cozy little home with Sir Claude would naturally and informally be secured.

Chapter XIII

Show Chapter Summary
On a rainy day, Maisie and her stepfather, Sir Claude, take shelter in the National Gallery. He calls the religious paintings a "silly superstition," which he clarifies is a comment on the affectation of admiring them. Maisie expresses concern that her governess, Mrs. Wix, will be dismissed. Sir Claude reassures her, explaining that he and her mother have an arrangement to let each other do what they want. On another day in a tea shop, Sir Claude asks Maisie what her father would do if they were to go away together. They discuss being afraid of Maisie's mother. Maisie says she is also afraid of Mrs. Beale. Sir Claude admits he is as well. When Maisie asks if he has seen Mrs. Beale, he says no, but that she has written to him. He then says Maisie has eaten five buns, and she corrects him, saying she had three. Shortly after, Mrs. Wix tells Maisie that Sir Claude has been seeing Mrs. Beale. When Maisie says Sir Claude denied it, Mrs. Wix says she learned it from visiting Mrs. Beale herself. Mrs. Wix cries that they will take Maisie away, and Maisie cries too. They agree not to confront Sir Claude. The next day, Sir Claude takes Maisie in a cab to her father’s new house in Regent’s Park. He says he has brought her to see Mrs. Beale. While still in the cab, he tells Maisie she must decide whether to go in or not. He explains that if she goes in, Mrs. Beale may keep her, and that he cannot leave her mother to form a new family with Maisie and Mrs. Wix. Maisie asks if he will visit her often, and after hesitating, he agrees. Maisie gets out of the cab. Inside the house, waiting for Mrs. Beale, Maisie asks what will happen to Mrs. Wix. Sir Claude replies that she should have thought of that sooner.

[Original]

This might moreover have been taken to be the sense of a remark made by her stepfather as—one rainy day when the streets were all splash and two umbrellas unsociable and the wanderers had sought shelter in the National Gallery—Maisie sat beside him staring rather sightlessly at a roomful of pictures which he had mystified her much by speaking of with a bored sigh as a "silly superstition." They represented, with patches of gold and cataracts of purple, with stiff saints and angular angels, with ugly Madonnas and uglier babies, strange prayers and prostrations; so that she at first took his words for a protest against devotional idolatry—all the more that he had of late often come with her and with Mrs. Wix to morning church, a place of worship of Mrs. Wix's own choosing, where there was nothing of that sort; no haloes on heads, but only, during long sermons, beguiling backs of bonnets, and where, as her governess always afterwards observed, he gave the most earnest attention. It presently appeared, however, that his reference was merely to the affectation of admiring such ridiculous works—an admonition that she received from him as submissively as she received everything.
