Chapter XIV

Show Chapter Summary
Mrs. Beale greets Maisie with a great show of affection. Maisie tells Sir Claude that Mrs. Beale is beautiful, and he agrees. The conversation turns to Sir Claude having previously lied to Maisie about visiting Mrs. Beale. Maisie says she knew he had lied because Mrs. Wix told her. Mrs. Beale reveals that Mrs. Wix recently visited her, admitted to seeing Sir Claude, and begged Mrs. Beale to “spare” him. Mrs. Beale kissed Maisie and declared she would not spare him. Maisie asks if Sir Claude will visit often. Mrs. Beale says that she has “squared” Maisie’s father, who is happy that Sir Claude has also quarreled with Maisie’s mother. It is decided that Maisie will stay and live with Mrs. Beale. Sir Claude promises to pack her things and bring them the next day, and he helps her take off her coat. They tell Maisie she will be a "duty" who will "save" them. When Maisie asks about lessons, Mrs. Beale promises she will attend courses and lectures with both her and Sir Claude. Maisie asks what will happen to Mrs. Wix. As he leaves, Sir Claude promises to “square” her. After he departs, Maisie says to Mrs. Beale that everyone will be squared, and Mrs. Beale embraces her.

Chapter XV

Show Chapter Summary
While playing the piano, a girl named Maisie is told by Susan Ash that Sir Claude is downstairs. Maisie goes down, hugs Sir Claude, and he invites her to go out. Five minutes later, they take a hansom to Hyde Park and then walk to Kensington Gardens. In the gardens, Sir Claude points out a man and a woman walking in the distance. Maisie stops and identifies the woman as her mother, Ida. Sir Claude, who believed Ida was in Brussels, looks closer and confirms it is her. The couple in the distance halts, then turns around and starts walking toward them. As they approach, Sir Claude lights a cigarette. Maisie takes Sir Claude's arm, causing them to stop. The other couple also stops. The woman, Ida, walks directly up to them while her male companion takes a wider path. Ida confronts Sir Claude, asking what he is doing with her daughter. Sir Claude asks who the man with her is. Ida glares at Maisie and tells her to go to the gentleman. Sir Claude grabs Maisie's arm and tells Ida that Maisie is his now, stating he has her from her father. Ida argues with him, then opens her arms to Maisie. Sir Claude lets the girl go. Ida embraces Maisie for a moment, then pushes her away and tells her to go to "the Captain." When Maisie questions the name, Sir Claude laughs. Ida calls Sir Claude loathsome and again orders Maisie to be off. As Maisie backs away, Sir Claude yells a curse at Ida. Maisie flees from the argument, running toward the other man.

[Original]

It was Susan Ash who came to her with the news: "He's downstairs, miss, and he do look beautiful." In the schoolroom at her father's, which had pretty blue curtains, she had been making out at the piano a lovely little thing, as Mrs. Beale called it, a "Moonlight Berceuse" sent her through the post by Sir Claude, who considered that her musical education had been deplorably neglected and who, the last months at her mother's, had been on the point of making arrangements for regular lessons. She knew from him familiarly that the real thing, as he said, was shockingly dear and that anything else was a waste of money, and she therefore rejoiced the more at the sacrifice represented by this composition, of which the price, five shillings, was marked on the cover and which was evidently the real thing.

Chapter XVI

Show Chapter Summary
A girl, Maisie, meets a Captain and tells him that Sir Claude called her mother a "damned old brute." The Captain first laughs, then repeats her words. Maisie suggests her mother tried to provoke Sir Claude, but the Captain calls her mother an angel. The Captain takes Maisie's hand, and they walk to a pair of chairs. He explains that her mother asked him to look after her while she confronted the "real culprit." He tells Maisie that her mother is the best friend he has ever had. Maisie mentions that she and Sir Claude had mistaken him for other men, Lord Eric and the Count. The Captain corrects her, stating her mother never knew Lord Eric. He tells Maisie never to believe any harm of her mother and praises her character extensively, saying she has suffered and never had justice. Maisie begins to cry and asks the Captain if he loves her mother. He stammers but then says he is tremendously fond of her and calls her an angel again. Maisie sobs. When she implores him to say he loves her mother, he says, "Of course I love her, damn it, you know!" Maisie jumps up and declares that she loves her mother too. The Captain asks Maisie if she will come back to her mother. Maisie says her mother won't have her, especially with Sir Claude. The Captain clarifies it would be in a different place and that her mother will agree if he asks. Maisie asks if he will be there, and he replies, "some day." He then offers to take her with them for an hour and says he will ask her mother immediately. Maisie sees Sir Claude approaching and tells the Captain to leave without meeting him. Before he goes, she asks if he will live with her mother, and he replies, "One of these days." She says Sir Claude won't be the first to leave the marriage. As they say goodbye, Maisie asks him to love her mother "always." She then runs to meet Sir Claude. As she leaves, she hears the Captain say, "Oh I'm in for it!" and sees him and her mother walk off in the same direction. Sir Claude asks Maisie who the man was and what they talked about. Maisie repeatedly claims not to know and says she wasn't paying attention. Sir Claude calls her a dunce and falls silent for the rest of their walk. At the gate, he hails a cab, puts her in it without looking at her, tosses money for the fare onto the seat, tells the driver the destination, and walks away.

Chapter XVII

Show Chapter Summary
For several days, Sir Claude does not visit. Mrs. Beale's attitude changes. She questions Maisie about an incident with the Captain and demonstrates she already knows what happened between Sir Claude and his wife. Mrs. Beale cries in front of Maisie. Three days after an incident in Kensington Gardens, Sir Claude sends Maisie a message. Mrs. Beale then admits to Maisie that she sees Sir Claude secretly but does not say how or where. She tells Maisie that Sir Claude cannot visit them at Regent's Park. Mrs. Beale begins acting as a messenger, carrying notes between Sir Claude and Maisie almost daily. She tells Maisie that Sir Claude has improved her character. Prompted by Sir Claude, Mrs. Beale organizes a new educational plan for Maisie. Nine books arrive from Sir Claude in one week, and Mrs. Beale begins reading with Maisie. Mrs. Beale stops receiving visitors, telling Maisie it is for her education. Maisie and Mrs. Beale begin attending lectures at an institution; they often rush out of the house to get there on time. Maisie looks for Sir Claude on these outings but never sees him. One day, Mrs. Beale announces they are going to the Exhibition at Earl's Court that night. She confesses that Sir Claude might meet them there, having told her to bring Maisie so he could try to see her. When Maisie asks why he cannot visit them directly, Mrs. Beale explains that Sir Claude has an idea about not getting Maisie "mixed up" in their relationship. Maisie asks Mrs. Beale if she minds. Mrs. Beale says she does not. Maisie then proposes to tell Sir Claude that evening that neither of them minds and to ask him why he does.

Chapter XVIII

Show Chapter Summary
At an Exhibition, Mrs. Beale first encourages a child, Maisie, to do something, but then withdraws her permission. Maisie looks for Sir Claude in the gardens but cannot find him. Lacking money for the side-shows, she and Mrs. Beale wait. While standing before a poster, they see a man and a woman come out of a booth. Mrs. Beale recognizes the man as Beale, Maisie’s father, who was believed to be away on a yacht. Beale and the woman turn and walk away. Mrs. Beale calls him a liar and says he never left. Maisie asks who the woman is, and Mrs. Beale says she is a new woman he has been with since Tuesday. The couple then turns and walks back toward them. Mrs. Beale identifies the woman as Mrs. Cuddon. A rapid confrontation follows, during which the woman, Mrs. Cuddon, recognizes them, cries out, and vanishes. Sir Claude is also present but is not seen by Beale. Mrs. Beale says something to Beale about his "new one," he retorts, and she replies loudly. Beale takes Maisie, puts her into a hansom cab, and gets in with her. He gives the driver an address. Inside the cab, he puts his arm around Maisie and trembles. They drive for a long time and arrive at a house. Beale opens the door with a key and takes Maisie upstairs into a decorated drawing-room. They wait together in the room. Maisie asks if the woman is a rich countess. Her father confirms she is an American Countess and says he wants her to see Maisie. He calls Mrs. Beale a fool for misidentifying the woman. He shows Maisie things around the room, gives her chocolates from a box, and sits her on his knee, stroking her hair. He then becomes restless as they continue to wait.

Reconstructing these things later, Maisie theorized that she would have asked him a question at this point, had not the silence into which he charmed or scared her—she could scarcely tell which—come from his suddenly making her feel his arm around her, feel, as he drew her close, that he was agitated in a way he had never yet shown her. It struck her he trembled, trembled too much to speak, and this had the effect of making her, with an emotion which, though it had begun to throb in an instant, by no means all dread, conform to his ominous quiet.

[Original]

The act of possession that his pressure in a manner advertised came back to her after the longest of the long intermissions that had ever let anything come back. It took her but a minute to surrender to this discovery, which, in the form of his present embrace, suggested a purpose in him prodigiously reaffirmed and with that a confused confidence. She neither knew exactly what he had done nor what he was doing; she could only, altogether impressed and rather proud, vibrate with the sense that he had jumped up to do something and that she had as quickly become a part of it.

Chapter XIX

Show Chapter Summary
A man, Beale, lights a cigarette and smokes in his daughter Maisie’s face. He announces he is going to America and asks her to come with him. She eventually agrees to go anywhere with him. He asks about her mother, and Maisie tells him about seeing her in a park with a gentleman. Beale accuses Maisie of having already made a deal to stay with her step-parents, calling them criminals and her a "monster" for siding with them. He warns her they will abandon her and asks if she will risk it. He then confirms that if he goes to America, she will never see him again. In response, Maisie says she cannot give him up. A vehicle arrives, and the Countess enters the room. Beale tells the Countess that Maisie has refused their offer. The Countess invites Maisie to Spa. Maisie asks to be sent home in a cab. Downstairs, Beale gives Maisie a final hug. When Maisie says she has no money for the cab, the Countess gives her a handful of coins. Her father disappears. The Countess puts Maisie in the cab and sends it away. Inside the cab, Maisie looks at the money and sees that it is a handful of gold sovereigns.

[Original]

When he had lighted a cigarette and begun to smoke in her face it was as if he had struck with the match the note of some queer clumsy ferment of old professions, old scandals, old duties, a dim perception of what he possessed in her and what, if everything had only—damn it!—been totally different, she might still be able to give him. What she was able to give him, however, as his blinking eyes seemed to make out through the smoke, would be simply what he should be able to get from her. To give something, to give here on the spot, was all her own desire. Among the old things that came back was her little instinct of keeping the peace; it made her wonder more sharply what particular thing she could do or not do, what particular word she could speak or not speak, what particular line she could take or not take, that might for every one, even for the Countess, give a better turn to the crisis.

Chapter XX

Show Chapter Summary
While Mrs. Beale is out late, the housemaid Susan Ash persuades Maisie to go to bed and to use one of her gold sovereigns to pay for a cab. The next day, Maisie gives the rest of the sovereigns to Mrs. Beale, who calls the money "the wages of sin," puts it in her pocket, and says she will send it back. Mrs. Beale asks Susan for the sovereign she received, but Susan refuses. A few days later, while Mrs. Beale is out, Sir Claude arrives and directs Susan to pack. Sir Claude, Maisie, and Susan travel by cab from London to a hotel in Folkestone. Sir Claude has decided to take Maisie abroad, away from both Mrs. Beale and his wife, Ida. He left a note for Mrs. Beale before departing. While Maisie and Sir Claude are sitting on a bench in the hotel garden, Maisie’s mother, Ida, appears unexpectedly. Ida explains that she went to Mrs. Beale's house and a maid told her where they had gone. Maisie tells her mother they are going to France. Ida says she is ill and also going abroad. She then asks to speak with Maisie alone. Sir Claude is reluctant to leave, but Ida insists. After a brief argument, Sir Claude leaves them. Ida then says to Maisie, "I am good, love."

[Original]

The money was far too much even for a fee in a fairy-tale, and in the absence of Mrs. Beale, who, though the hour was now late, had not yet returned to the Regent's Park, Susan Ash, in the hall, as loud as Maisie was low and as bold as she was bland, produced, on the exhibition offered under the dim vigil of the lamp that made the place a contrast to the child's recent scene of light, the half-crown that an unsophisticated cabman could pronounce to be the least he would take. It was apparently long before Mrs. Beale would arrive, and in the interval Maisie had been induced by the prompt Susan not only to go to bed like a darling dear, but, in still richer expression of that character, to devote to the repayment of obligations general as well as particular one of the sovereigns in the ordered array that, on the dressing-table upstairs, was naturally not less dazzling to a lone orphan of a housemaid than to the subject of the manœuvres of a quartette.

Translation

The money was excessive, even for a fairy tale. With Mrs. Beale still absent, despite the late hour—she hadn't returned to Regent's Park—Susan Ash, in the hall, spoke loudly, in contrast to Maisie's quiet demeanor. Susan was also bold, in contrast to her own pleasantness. Under the dim light of the lamp, which made the hall a stark contrast to the child's earlier scene of brightness, Susan revealed the half-crown. Even a simple cab driver would know that was the minimum fare. Mrs. Beale wouldn't be back for a while. In the meantime, the decisive Susan had persuaded Maisie to go to bed, like a good little girl. Even better, Maisie, in a particularly generous act, offered to repay both general and specific debts using one of the gold coins from the collection arranged on the dressing table upstairs. The coins were surely as dazzling to the orphaned housemaid as they were to the target of the four people's manipulations.

[Original]

This subject went to sleep with her property gathered into a knotted handkerchief, the largest that could be produced and lodged under her pillow; but the explanations that on the morrow were inevitably more complete with Mrs. Beale than they had been with her humble friend found their climax in a surrender also more becomingly free. There were explanations indeed that Mrs. Beale had to give as well as to ask, and the most striking of these was to the effect that it was dreadful for a little girl to take money from a woman who was simply the vilest of their sex.

Translation

Maisie, clutching her possessions in a knotted handkerchief—the biggest one she could find, now tucked under her pillow—fell asleep. But the next day, her explanations to Mrs. Beale, which were far more detailed than they had been to Susan, culminated in a more willingly given surrender. Mrs. Beale had explanations to offer as well, and the most dramatic of these was that it was awful for a little girl to accept money from a woman who was the most vile of all women.

[Original]

The sovereigns were examined with some attention, the result of which, however, was to make the author of that statement desire to know what, if one really went into the matter, they could be called but the wages of sin. Her companion went into it merely so far as the question of what then they were to do with them; on which Mrs. Beale, who had by this time put them into her pocket, replied with dignity and with her hand on the place: "We're to send them back on the spot!" Susan, the child soon afterwards learnt, had been invited to contribute to this act of restitution her one appropriated coin; but a closer clutch of the treasure showed in her private assurance to Maisie that there was a limit to the way she could be "done." Maisie had been open with Mrs. Beale about the whole of last night's transaction; but she now found herself on the part of their indignant inferior a recipient of remarks that were so many ringing tokens of that lady's own suppressions.

[Original]

One of these bore upon the extraordinary hour—it was three in the morning if she really wanted to know—at which Mrs. Beale had re-entered the house; another, in accents as to which Maisie's criticism was still intensely tacit, characterised her appeal as such a "gime," such a "shime," as one had never had to put up with; a third treated with some vigour the question of the enormous sums due belowstairs, in every department, for gratuitous labour and wasted zeal. Our young lady's consciousness was indeed mainly filled for several days with the apprehension created by the too slow subsidence of her attendant's sense of wrong. These days would become terrific like the Revolutions she had learnt by heart in Histories if an outbreak in the kitchen should crown them; and to promote that prospect she had through Susan's eyes more than one glimpse of the way in which Revolutions are prepared.

One of the complaints referenced the strange hour—three in the morning, if the truth be told—that Mrs. Beale had come back into the house. For several days, our young lady’s awareness was preoccupied by the worry that her attendant’s sense of grievance wouldn't diminish. [Original]

Susan’s account suggested that the initial ignition of the simmering discontent—the very factor that made things begin to crackle—stemmed from someone being branded a vile, low-down thief for refusing to surrender their own possessions. Chapter XXI

Show Chapter Summary
Ida keeps her daughter, Maisie, in the garden and gives her a long explanation. As they sit together, Ida’s hand rests on Maisie's and adjusts her hair and ribbons. Ida tells Maisie she is "criminally good" but has stopped fighting for her. She states that she is very ill, her doctor says she must go away, and she is considering South Africa. She also tells Maisie that her father wishes she were dead. Ida takes a small object out of her purse. Maisie then mentions a Captain who spoke kindly of Ida. Ida becomes angry, calls the Captain a "cad," and insults Maisie for mentioning him. Maisie reveals she had hoped the Captain was the one taking Ida to South Africa. Ida's anger subsides. She puts the object back in her purse, calls Maisie a "dreadful dismal deplorable little thing," turns, and walks away. Maisie sits alone until a gong sounds and Sir Claude appears in a doorway. She goes to him on the lawn. They walk to the house, and Maisie tells him her mother is going to South Africa. He stops walking, laughs, then becomes serious. Maisie also tells him that her mother took money out of her purse and then put it back. After dinner, Maisie and Sir Claude smoke on a terrace and then walk in the garden. He says he is restless and needs to walk alone, telling her to go upstairs to bed. Before she leaves, he says, "I'm free—I'm free." Maisie repeats his words. He says they will go to France tomorrow, which she also repeats. He again says he is free, and she echoes him. He then draws her close, kisses her goodnight, and sends her upstairs. He turns back to look at the boats as Maisie goes up.

[Original]

A good deal of the rest of Ida's visit was devoted to explaining, as it were, so extraordinary a statement. This explanation was more copious than any she had yet indulged in, and as the summer twilight gathered and she kept her child in the garden she was conciliatory to a degree that let her need to arrange things a little perceptibly peep out. It was not merely that she explained; she almost conversed; all that was wanting was that she should have positively chattered a little less. It was really the occasion of Maisie's life on which her mother was to have most to say to her.

Translation

Much of the remainder of Ida's visit was spent clarifying such an unusual declaration. This explanation was more extensive than anything she’d offered before, and as evening approached and she kept her daughter in the garden, she became accommodating to a degree that allowed her need to manage things to become evident. She didn't simply explain; she almost held a conversation. The only thing missing was that she would have talked a little less. This was the moment in Maisie's life when her mother was to have the most to say to her.

Oh, there would have been things to be surprised by if one had given in to it; and it was fortunate that they were alone together, without Sir Claude or Mrs. Wix or even Mrs.

[Original]

Beale to catch an imprudent glance. Though profuse and prolonged her ladyship was not exhaustively lucid, and her account of her situation, so far as it could be called descriptive, was a muddle of inconsequent things, bruised fruit of an occasion she had rather too lightly affronted. None of them were really thought out and some were even not wholly insincere. It was as if she had asked outright what better proof could have been wanted of her goodness and her greatness than just this marvellous consent to give up what she had so cherished.

Chapter XXII

Show Chapter Summary
On a Channel boat, Sir Claude sits with Maisie's head in his lap and a housemaid's head on his chest. They arrive in Boulogne, France. Sir Claude sends Maisie and the housemaid, Susan Ash, out for a walk. Later, Maisie walks with Sir Claude and asks when they will go to Paris. He tells her Paris is too expensive and they are in Boulogne for three or four days to save money. He then says they are waiting for Mrs. Wix, who he reveals has sent him a telegram after seeing Maisie's mother in London. The next day, Maisie and Sir Claude go to the quay in the rain to meet the boat. Sir Claude boards the vessel and returns with Mrs. Wix. At the hotel, Maisie helps Mrs. Wix, who tells her that Sir Claude paid for her new clothes and the trip. Later, the three of them sit in a salon where Sir Claude has a fire lit. After some general conversation, Mrs. Wix announces that Maisie's mother sent her to them.

A distant foghorn, the creak of the house settling, the faint whisper of the wind against the windows. He knew he wouldn't be able to sleep again. The next day it seemed to her indeed at the bottom—down too far, in shuddering plunges, even to leave her a sense, on the Channel boat, of the height at which Sir Claude remained and which had never in every way been so great as when, much in the wet, though in the angle of a screen of canvas, he sociably sat with his stepdaughter's head in his lap and that of Mrs. Beale's housemaid fairly pillowed on his breast. Maisie was surprised to learn as they drew into port that they had had a lovely passage; but this emotion, at Boulogne, was speedily quenched in others, above all in the great ecstasy of a larger impression of life. She was "abroad" and she gave herself up to it, responded to it, in the bright air, before the pink houses, among the bare-legged fishwives and the red-legged soldiers, with the instant certitude of a vocation.

It was perhaps half an effect of her present renovations, as if her clothes had been somebody's else: she had at any rate never produced such an impression of high colour, of a redness associated in Maisie's mind at that pitch either with measles or with "habits." Maisie knew when this did come how anxiously it had been awaited by the youngest member of the party. "Her ladyship packed me off—she almost put me into the cab!" That was what Mrs. Wix at last brought out.

Translation

Chapter XXIII

Show Chapter Summary
Sir Claude stands at a window with his back to Mrs. Wix and Maisie. Mrs. Wix tells Maisie that Sir Claude's wife visited her the day before, coming straight from the station. She says his wife helped her, gave her a ten-pound note, and said she wants Mrs. Wix to have Maisie. Upon hearing about the money, Sir Claude laughs loudly. Mrs. Wix rises and stands by the fire. She tells Sir Claude that his wife wants him to get rid of a person from Mrs. Beale's named Susan. Maisie says she doesn't want Susan there. Sir Claude agrees to take Susan back himself. Mrs. Wix objects, suggesting he just pay her fare, but he insists. Sir Claude turns from the window and asks if his wife visited alone. Mrs. Wix says a man was waiting in the cab but did not come up. Sir Claude laughs, walks about the room, and asks who the man was. Mrs. Wix reveals his name is Mr. Tischbein. She then explains that his wife came to her because Maisie needs a "decent person," implying this is to replace Mrs. Beale. Sir Claude defends Mrs. Beale. Sir Claude looks for his hat, and Maisie gets it for him. He says he needs some air. Mrs. Wix accuses him of being afraid of Mrs. Beale. Standing at the door, Sir Claude looks between Mrs. Wix and Maisie, admits, "Yes. I'm simply afraid of her," and leaves the room.

Chapter XXIV

Show Chapter Summary
At an evening meal, a young lady explains the menu to Mrs. Wix. Later, Maisie and Mrs. Wix go to their sitting room while Sir Claude stays downstairs to smoke and talk. Mrs. Wix sits on a sofa, and Maisie attempts to divert her with conversation. Near ten o'clock, Sir Claude enters the room holding up a letter. He approaches Mrs. Wix, takes two papers from the envelope, and gives one to her to read. After reading it, Mrs. Wix stands up, drops the letter, and calls its contents "abominable." Sir Claude explains the letter is from Maisie's father to Mrs. Beale, ending their relationship. Sir Claude offers the letter to Maisie, but Mrs. Wix snatches it, hides it behind her back, and forbids Maisie from seeing it. An argument follows between Sir Claude and Mrs. Wix. He states that he must go to Mrs. Beale. Mrs. Wix warns him that if he sees her again, he is lost. Sir Claude promises to return by Saturday and details the comfortable arrangements he has made for them. Mrs. Wix accuses him of being afraid of Mrs. Beale, then throws herself on the sofa and cries. Sir Claude tells them both to go to bed, announcing that he will leave on an early boat. He opens his arms to Maisie, and she flies into them for a hug. Mrs. Wix jumps to her feet and begs Sir Claude not to go, offering to go in his place to "settle" Mrs. Beale. Sir Claude hesitates, then hugs Maisie again. He tells Maisie to be nice to Mrs. Wix and then leaves the room.

[Original]

It continued to rain so hard that our young lady's private dream of explaining the Continent to their visitor had to contain a provision for some adequate treatment of the weather. At the table d'hôte that evening she threw out a variety of lights: this was the second ceremony of the sort she had sat through, and she would have neglected her privilege and dishonoured her vocabulary—which indeed consisted mainly of the names of dishes—if she had not been proportionately ready to dazzle with interpretations. Preoccupied and overawed, Mrs. Wix was apparently dim: she accepted her pupil's version of the mysteries of the menu in a manner that might have struck the child as the depression of a credulity conscious not so much of its needs as of its dimensions.

Chapter XXV

Show Chapter Summary
Maisie is woken and squeezed in the dawn, falling back onto her couch. Later, she gets up to dress and finds a sixpence on the carpet. With Mrs. Wix, she uses a carriage and is served food by waiters. They drive on a cliff, walk through a port and streets, and climb to an old rampart. They sit on a bastion, look at the town, and walk through a church, where Mrs. Wix says she should have been a Catholic. They return to the rampart the next morning. An old woman on their bench gets up, says goodbye, and leaves. Maisie and Mrs. Wix bob up in response and sit down again. Maisie asks why the four of them—herself, Mrs. Wix, Sir Claude, and Mrs. Beale—cannot be together. Mrs. Wix reacts in shock, calling the idea a "crime." They argue. Maisie suggests Mrs. Wix could remain her companion. Mrs. Wix refuses and questions Maisie's morality. They discuss whether Sir Claude and Mrs. Beale are "free." Maisie reveals that the Countess gave her money, which she then gave to Mrs. Beale, who sent it back. The argument intensifies. Maisie declares her love for Mrs. Beale, and Mrs. Wix says Mrs. Beale is as bad as Maisie's father. Maisie shrieks in denial. Mrs. Wix stands up, and Maisie stands as well. Mrs. Wix walks a few steps away and they stare at each other. Maisie asks if Sir Claude pays Mrs. Wix. Mrs. Wix calls Maisie a "waif" and marches away. Maisie falls back onto the bench and sobs.

A wave of confusion washed over Maisie. What was she supposed to *do*? The directive was simple, almost childish, yet its implications were vast, like a landscape seen through a distorting lens. She wanted to run, to escape the suffocating weight of the unspoken. But where could she go?

She looked back at Mrs. Wix again. The woman’s gaze seemed to pierce through her, as if she were a glass, and Mrs. Wix, a determined examiner. The silence stretched, becoming thick and heavy.

Maisie, taking a ragged breath, moved to the window. The garden outside was bathed in a pale, mournful light. The world seemed distant, unreal. She clutched the window frame, a desperate attempt to find something solid to hold onto.

Chapter XXVI

Show Chapter Summary
After a conflict, Maisie and Mrs. Wix reconcile. They go home, and Mrs. Wix holds Maisie's hand. Later, in a saloon, they have coffee and liqueurs while waiting for a carriage. Mrs. Wix asks Maisie if she has a "moral sense." They take a carriage ride and then walk on the beach at the coachman's suggestion. They sit on the sand, where Mrs. Wix again asks Maisie about her moral sense. They return to their rooms in the evening, where Mrs. Wix hugs Maisie tightly and speaks about what she has had to learn and say for the child's sake. Maisie stands on a balcony watching a café and listening to musicians. She goes back inside and asks Mrs. Wix if "it" is a crime. Mrs. Wix says it is and that "he" is committing it by being "with her." Maisie tells Mrs. Wix to trust her, and Mrs. Wix puts her to bed. The next morning, no letter arrives from Sir Claude. Maisie and Mrs. Wix walk to a rampart. Mrs. Wix says Sir Claude is afraid of "her" and asks Maisie if she is jealous. Maisie says yes and adds that she would kill "her" if she were unkind to "him." Mrs. Wix cries, and they hold hands. Mrs. Wix says, "I adore him," and Maisie replies, "Oh I know!" A bell summons them to luncheon. They walk back to the hotel and go up to their rooms. Maisie opens the door to their saloon and sees Mrs. Beale standing inside among her bags. Mrs. Beale holds out her arms and says, "I'm free, I'm free!"

[Original]

Nothing so dreadful of course could be final or even for many minutes prolonged: they rushed together again too soon for either to feel that either had kept it up, and though they went home in silence it was with a vivid perception for Maisie that her companion's hand had closed upon her. That hand had shown altogether, these twenty-four hours, a new capacity for closing, and one of the truths the child could least resist was that a certain greatness had now come to Mrs. Wix. The case was indeed that the quality of her motive surpassed the sharpness of her angles; both the combination and the singularity of which things, when in the afternoon they used the carriage, Maisie could borrow from the contemplative hush of their grandeur the freedom to feel to the utmost.

In the evening upstairs they had another strange sensation, as to which Maisie couldn't afterwards have told you whether it was bang in the middle or quite at the beginning that her companion sounded with fresh emphasis the note of the moral sense. What mattered was merely that she did exclaim, and again, as at first appeared, most disconnectedly: "God help me, it does seem to peep out!" There was a point at which she seized the child and hugged her as close as in the old days of partings and returns; at which she was visibly at a loss how to make up to such a victim for such contaminations: appealing, as to what she had done and was doing, in bewilderment, in explanation, in supplication, for reassurance, for pardon and even outright for pity.

Mrs. Beale arrives, causing Mrs. Wix to sink into a chair. Mrs. Beale embraces Maisie. Maisie sees that Sir Claude's luggage is not with Mrs. Beale and asks if she has come alone. Mrs. Beale confirms she is alone, pats Maisie’s cheek, and announces, "I'm free, I'm free!" Maisie asks where Sir Claude is and if he will come. She also tells Maisie she has brought her a new hat. A waiter appears and reminds them that lunch is half over. Mrs. Beale tells Mrs. Wix and Maisie to go wash their hands, directs Mrs. Wix to "attend to my daughter," and goes into a neighboring room. Mrs. Wix pulls Maisie into their own room. Chapter XXVIII

Show Chapter Summary
At a meal, Mrs. Beale sits at a table and talks to her neighbor, turning her head and shoulder away from Maisie. For the rest of the day, Mrs. Beale spends time with Maisie and Mrs. Wix, keeping them with her. She takes them walking and driving and proposes they go to a concert, but the plan is cancelled. Throughout the day, Mrs. Beale acts as their guide, talking about her travels and explaining continental life. Before dinner, Mrs. Beale pushes Maisie into a room and helps her get ready. She tells Maisie she is going to divorce Maisie's father to marry Sir Claude. Mrs. Beale explains that Sir Claude paid Maisie's mother to relinquish her parental rights, a deal that will allow him to get a divorce. Maisie says that neither Sir Claude nor Mrs. Beale will get their divorces, admitting she heard this from Mrs. Wix. Mrs. Beale replies that Mrs. Wix is mistaken and that she left Sir Claude because he has not yet gotten his divorce. Mrs. Beale kisses Maisie and asks her to find out if Mrs. Wix likes her. Later, Maisie asks Mrs. Wix if she has been won over and would accept Mrs. Beale as her guardian instead of Sir Claude. Mrs. Wix says that while Mrs. Beale has been polite, she would not like her as a guardian as much as she likes Sir Claude. When Mrs. Wix asks Maisie if she accepts Mrs. Beale, Maisie says no, stating she wants "Him alone or nobody." Mrs. Wix asks, "Not even me?" Maisie begins to undress and tells Mrs. Wix, "Oh you're nobody!"

Chapter XXIX

Show Chapter Summary
A young girl, Maisie, wakes up late to find her governess, Mrs. Wix, already dressed in her room. Mrs. Wix informs her that Sir Claude has arrived. Maisie gets out of bed and begins to get ready. While Mrs. Wix helps her dress, they talk. Mrs. Wix says Sir Claude is with "her" and that "she" will never leave. Mrs. Wix says Sir Claude is weak and that if Maisie and she abandon him, he will be ruined and trapped with the other woman forever. Mrs. Wix brushes Maisie's hair and kisses her cheek during their conversation. After dressing, Maisie decides she must see Sir Claude. Mrs. Wix refuses to go near them and forbids Maisie from entering the salon, saying it is no longer theirs. Mrs. Wix sinks into a chair and covers her face. Maisie grabs her hat and leaves the room alone. Maisie enters the salon, which is empty. Sir Claude steps in from the balcony. He pauses before greeting her, then holds out his hand, meets her, and kisses her. He says he has not seen Mrs. Beale. When Maisie moves toward the door of the room Mrs. Beale had occupied, Sir Claude stops her, saying he only wants to see Maisie. He tells her that he and Mrs. Beale have quarreled. Sir Claude suggests he and Maisie go out for breakfast. As they leave, he stops on the stairs to ask about Mrs. Wix. At the bottom of the stairs, he orders the landlady to send breakfast up to Mrs. Wix's room. The landlady asks about "Madame," and Sir Claude replies, "Nothing yet." He and Maisie then walk toward a café.

Chapter XXX

Show Chapter Summary
Sir Claude and Maisie sit at a table in a café along the quay. A waiter brings them café au lait and buttered rolls. Sir Claude asks if that will be enough food for her until lunch. He then tells her about his trip to London, his journey back, and asks what she and Mrs. Wix did while he was away. Maisie asks if they are going to have lunch with Mrs. Beale. Sir Claude avoids the question and instead asks what Mrs. Wix has said to Maisie about staying with them. Maisie says "Nothing," but then explains that Mrs. Beale has been very kind to Mrs. Wix. The waiter brings their breakfast and pours their coffee. Sir Claude sends the waiter away and continues questioning Maisie about Mrs. Beale's interactions with Mrs. Wix. Maisie says Mrs. Beale talked to Mrs. Wix all day and "made love to her." She asks if Sir Claude hasn't seen Mrs. Beale yet, and he insists he has not, stating he came back only to see Maisie. He confirms that Mrs. Beale will not be leaving, which makes the situation awkward. They order more coffee and rolls. Sir Claude tells Maisie he returned to ask her a question. He takes her hand and asks if Mrs. Wix would now stay with Mrs. Beale even without him, and Maisie says yes. After a long discussion about Mrs. Wix's feelings, Sir Claude asks Maisie if she will choose to let Mrs. Wix go and stay with him and Mrs. Beale. He proposes an arrangement where they would live abroad, with him living nearby but not in the same house. Maisie asks what would happen to Mrs. Wix, and Sir Claude replies that she would go back to London. When Maisie asks who will teach her, he says he will. Sir Claude calls the waiter and pays the bill. He asks Maisie if she would ever stay with Mrs. Wix and Mrs. Beale without him, and she replies, "Never." He asks her again to make her choice. Maisie asks for time to think and says she wants to see Mrs. Wix first. Sir Claude agrees. Maisie reminds him that she brought him and Mrs. Beale together. He laughs, gets up, and says, "Come!"

[Original]

After they were seated there it was different: the place was not below the hotel, but further along the quay; with wide, clear windows and a floor sprinkled with bran in a manner that gave it for Maisie something of the added charm of a circus. They had pretty much to themselves the painted spaces and the red plush benches; these were shared by a few scattered gentlemen who picked teeth, with facial contortions, behind little bare tables, and by an old personage in particular, a very old personage with a red ribbon in his buttonhole, whose manner of soaking buttered rolls in coffee and then disposing of them in the little that was left of the interval between his nose and chin might at a less anxious hour have cast upon Maisie an almost envious spell. They too had their café au lait and their buttered rolls, determined by Sir Claude's asking her if she could with that light aid wait till the hour of déjeuner. His allusion to this meal gave her, in the shaded sprinkled coolness, the scene, as she vaguely felt, of a sort of ordered mirrored licence, the haunt of those—the irregular, like herself—who went to bed or who rose too late, something to think over while she watched the white-aproned waiter perform as nimbly with plates and saucers as a certain conjurer her friend had in London taken her to a music-hall to see.

Translation

Once they were seated, things were different. They weren't below the hotel, but farther along the quay. It had wide, clear windows and a floor sprinkled with bran, which made it feel like a circus to Maisie. They practically had the painted space and the red plush benches to themselves, except for a few scattered gentlemen picking their teeth, contorting their faces behind small, bare tables. There was also a very old man, in particular, with a red ribbon in his buttonhole. His way of soaking buttered rolls in coffee and then dealing with them in the space between his nose and chin might have, at a less anxious time, made Maisie almost envious. They also had café au lait and buttered rolls, decided by Sir Claude's asking if she could, with that light sustenance, wait until lunch. His mention of lunch, in the cool, shaded room sprinkled with bran, gave her a feeling of an ordered, mirrored freedom. It was a place for the irregular, like herself, who went to bed or got up too late, something to consider as she watched the white-aproned waiter move with plates and saucers as nimbly as a conjurer she’d seen at a music hall in London with a friend.

[Original]

Sir Claude had presently begun to talk again, to tell her how London had looked and how long he had felt himself, on either side, to have been absent; all about Susan Ash too and the amusement as well as the difficulty he had had with her; then all about his return journey and the Channel in the night and the crowd of people coming over and the way there were always too many one knew. He spoke of other matters beside, especially of what she must tell him of the occupations, while he was away, of Mrs. Wix and her pupil. Chapter XXXI

Show Chapter Summary
A girl, Maisie, and a man, Sir Claude, walk around a town, looking in shop windows and going to the beach and pier. To prolong their walk, Sir Claude suggests they go to the train station to get newspapers. At the station, he buys eleven newspapers and three books. They stand near a train bound for Paris. Maisie asks Sir Claude to take her on the train, and he asks a porter when it departs. The porter says it leaves in two minutes and offers to get their tickets. Maisie tells him to, but Sir Claude hesitates and asks her if she has made a choice. The train departs without them. As they walk from the station, Maisie tells Sir Claude she will leave with him if he agrees to give up Mrs. Beale. They stop at a quay to watch a boat preparing to leave for Folkestone before returning to their inn. In the hotel lobby, they see the luggage of another woman, Mrs. Wix. They go upstairs and sit on the landing. Sir Claude says Mrs. Wix thinks Maisie has abandoned her. Maisie tells him that if he breaks up with Mrs. Beale, she will wait for him until Mrs. Wix has left on the boat. They enter their salon, where Mrs. Beale informs them that she has had an argument with Mrs. Wix, who is now leaving. Mrs. Wix then enters, dressed for travel, and asks Maisie to come with her. A confrontation ensues among the three adults. Mrs. Beale physically restrains Maisie, but Sir Claude makes her let go. Maisie states her condition: she will stay with Sir Claude only if he gives up Mrs. Beale. Sir Claude tells Mrs. Beale that he will never give her up. Upon hearing this, Maisie says goodbye to Sir Claude. Mrs. Beale also says goodbye and leaves the room. Sir Claude opens the door for Maisie and Mrs. Wix. Maisie and Sir Claude shake hands and say goodbye one last time. Maisie leaves with Mrs. Wix and they board the steamer to Folkestone just as it is departing. On the boat, Maisie tells Mrs. Wix that she looked back for Sir Claude but he was not there. Mrs. Wix states that he went back to Mrs. Beale, and Maisie replies that she knows.

[Original]

She remained out with him for a time of which she could take no measure save that it was too short for what she wished to make of it—an interval, a barrier indefinite, insurmountable. They walked about, they dawdled, they looked in shop-windows; they did all the old things exactly as if to try to get back all the old safety, to get something out of them that they had always got before. This had come before, whatever it was, without their trying, and nothing came now but the intenser consciousness of their quest and their subterfuge. The strangest thing of all was what had really happened to the old safety.

Translation

She stayed with him for an amount of time she couldn’t gauge, only that it was too brief for what she hoped to accomplish—a gap, an undefined, impassable wall. They strolled, they lingered, they peered in store windows; they repeated all their old habits, as if attempting to recapture the familiar comfort, to extract something they’d always found there. This had occurred before, whatever “this” was, effortlessly, but now all they encountered was a sharper awareness of their purpose and their deception. The most peculiar thing of all was what had become of that old sense of security.

[Original]

What had really happened was that Sir Claude was "free" and that Mrs. Beale was "free," and yet that the new medium was somehow still more oppressive than the old. She could feel that Sir Claude concurred with her in the sense that the oppression would be worst at the inn, where, till something should be settled, they would feel the want of something—of what could they call it but a footing? The question of the settlement loomed larger to her now: it depended, she had learned, so completely on herself.

The matter of the settlement loomed larger to her now: she had learned that it depended entirely on her.

[Original]

She must see Mrs. Wix before she could do her sum; therefore the longer before she saw her the more distant would be the ordeal.
